Vivien Bonvin Ph.D. Student - EPFL

COSMOGRAIL H0LiCOW IPT

About me

I was born and raised in Chermignon, a tiny village in the middle of the Swiss Alps.
I graduated with a degree in Physics from the Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Switzerland, in February 2013.
Since then, I am pursuing a Ph.D. degree at the Laboratory of Astrophysics of EPFL, that focuses in gravitational lensing and time-delay cosmography.

I am deeply involved in the organisation and promotion of the International Physicists' Tournament, of which I am the President since 2014.

I am enthusiastic about many things - science, music, literature, sport and computer stuff, to name only a few. Scroll down to see more !

Scientific interest

My work uses the strong gravitational lensing effect as a tool to constrain cosmological models.

In the COSMOGRAIL collaboration - COSmological MOnitoring of GRAvItational Lenses - we measure the time delays for most of the known lensed quasars, using dedicated telescopes. We aim to measure the time delays between the lensed images with a precision below 3%.

In the H0LiCOW collaboration - H0 Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring - we convert these time delays into a cosmological measurement of the Hubble Constant H0.

COSMOGRAIL H0LiCOW

First author publications

  • HOLiCOW V

    Bonvin et al., 2016

    New COSMOGRAIL time delays of HE0435−1223: H0 to 3.8% precision from strong lensing in a flat ΛCDM model.

  • COSMOGRAIL XV

    Bonvin et al., 2016

    Assessing the achievability and precision of time-delay measurements.

Softwares and codes

  • PyCS

    Tewes & Bonvin

    PyCS - Python Curve Shifting - is a software toolbox to estimate time delays between multiple images of gravitationally lensed quasars, developed within the COSMOGRAIL collaboration.

  • POUET

    Bonvin & Kuntzer

    POUET - Programming Observation Usefully at Euler Telescope - is a small, user-friendly interface that allows an easy night planning at the Swiss 1.2-m Leonhard Euler Telescope. Currently under heavy development.

  • IPT-connect

    Bonvin & Harazi

    IPT-connect is a python/django software used to keep track of the participants' results during each edition of the International Physicists' Tournament.

Co-author publications

  • HOLiCOW I

    Suyu et al., 2016

    H0 Lenses in COSMOGRAIL’s Wellspring: Program Overview.

  • H0LiCOW III

    Sluse et al., 2016

    Spectroscopic survey and galaxy-group identification of the strong gravitational lens system HE0435−1223.

  • H0LiCOW IV

    Wong et al., 2016

    Lens mass model of HE0435−1223 and blind measurement of its time-delay distance for cosmology.

  • GEAR

    Revaz et al., 2015

    Computational issues in chemo-dynamical modelling of the formation and evolution of galaxies.

  • TDC

    Liao et al., 2015

    Strong Lens Time Delay Challenge: II. Results of TDC1.

International Physicists' Tournament

I dedicate a large amount of my free time to the International Physicists' Tournament (or IPT), a physics competition at for University students.

The IPT sees 18 teams of six students from universities all around the world competing on 17 problems. The problems are available six months in advance for the teams to read, work, experiment and synthetize the results. During the competition, each team has to present their work, and debate with an opposing team about the strenght and flaws of their solution.

I took part for the first time in the IPT in 2011, as a participant in the Swiss Team and finished at the 3rd rank. In 2013, I was a member of the Local Organizing Committee (LOC) of the tournament, organised at EPFL, in Switzerland. In 2014, I became President of the LOC. Since 2014, I have been elected President of the Tournament.
